reference.title: Network and port requirements
reference.shortdesc: For proper communication, the IBM StoredIQ components must be able to connect to each other.

section.p:
You must enable network connectivity from the following locations:
The data server IP address to the gateway IP address on port 11103
The gateway IP address to and from the application stack IP address on port 8765 and 5432
Ports 80, 443, and 22 from the administrative workstation to the application stack and data server IP addresses
Port 22 from the administrative workstation to the gateway IP address

section.title: TCP: port ranges for the firewall
section.p:
To ensure the network access for desktop volumes, the following port ranges must be open through a firewall.
21000-21004
21100-21101
21110-21130
21200-21204

section.title: Default open ports
section.p: The following ports are open by default on the IBM StoredIQ.

By default, port 22 is open on all IBM StoredIQ hosts. The port is used for Secure Shell (SSH) communication and allows remote administration access to the VM. In general, traffic is encrypted using password authentication. To add a layer of security, you can establish key-based authentication for passwordless SSH logins to any of the IBM StoredIQ nodes in your environment as described in "configuring SSH key-based authentication” on page 45.

table.title: Default open ports on the AppStack
Default open ports on the IBM StoredIQ data server

row.entry: PROD-transport (IBM StoredIQ transport services; communication between the gateway and the data server)

table.title: Default open ports on the nodes in the Elasticsearch cluster

row.entry: SimpleHTTPServer (used for copying the siqelasticsearch.yml configuration file from the Elasticsearch node to the data server)

entry.p: You can restrict access to this port by either enabling Search Guard or by setting up a firewall. For more information, see “Securing Elasticsearch cluster communication with Search Guard” on page 51 or “Restricting access to port 9200 on Elasticsearch nodes” on page 52.

table.title: Default open ports on the IBM StoredIQ gateway

row.entry: PROD-transport (IBM StoredIQ transport services; communication between the gateway and the data server)

p.b: Supported chain and rules on the IBM StoredIQ gateway

section.p: In iptables, the following firewall and chain rules are defined:

p.b: Open ports for desktop client access to the data server

section.p: To open ports for desktop client access to the data server on OVA deployed systems, follow these steps:

ol.li: Log in to the data server as root and run this command: python /usr/local/storediq/bin/util/port_handler.pyc -e desktop

Run this command: iptables -L INPUT
In the output of the command, check the list position of the rule that is named PROD-reject, for example, the 6th position on the list.
Run this command: iptables -A INPUT -j PROD-reject

Run this command:iptables -D INPUT list_position
list_position is the position number of the PROD-reject rule that you determined in step 2.
Run the following command: python /usr/local/storediq/bin/util/port_handler.pyc -e desktop

section.p: Tip: These steps are required only on an IBM StoredIQ OVA deployed system. The correct ports are open on an upgraded system.

link.desc: IBM StoredIQ is deployed as virtual appliances and is supported in VMware ESXi 5.0 (all fix pack levels) or VMware ESXi 6.0 (all fix pack levels) environments. You must have a virtual infrastructure that meets the IBM StoredIQ hardware requirements.
To size an environment precisely, you must understand the factors such as harvest frequency, complexity of the source, and use case scenarios that drive application use and action execution.
Before a deployment, verify that you meet these prerequisites.
Using the IBM License Metric Tool, you can generate license consumption reports that count IBM StoredIQ license usage
Plan and implement specific security measures to protect the application and the data it manages, especially when you deploy IBM StoredIQ into sensitive environments.
When you plan a deployment of IBM StoredIQ, evaluate several infrastructure considerations.

IBM StoredIQ is deployed as virtual appliances and is supported in VMware ESXi 5.0 (all fix pack levels) or VMware ESXi 6.0 (all fix pack levels) environments. You must have a virtual infrastructure that meets the IBM StoredIQ hardware requirements.
To size an environment precisely, you must understand the factors such as harvest frequency, complexity of the source, and use case scenarios that drive application use and action execution.
Before a deployment, verify that you meet these prerequisites.
Using the IBM License Metric Tool, you can generate license consumption reports that count IBM StoredIQ license usage
Plan and implement specific security measures to protect the application and the data it manages, especially when you deploy IBM StoredIQ into sensitive environments.
